questions.text: A patient suffering from stroke presented with features of Weber's syndrome. Which of these findings will not be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
In Weber's syndrome, there is involvement of the midbrain. Posterior cerebral artery (PCA) is the involved vessel.

The following lesions are seen-

Ipsilateral occulomotor nerve palsy -

  • 'Down and out' eye due to unopposed action of 4th and 6th
  • Ptosis
  • Dilated and unresponsive pupil

Corticospinal and corticobulbar track involvement -

  • Contralateral hemiparesis
  • Contralateral paralysis of face

A third nerve palsy with contralateral ataxia is seen in Claude's syndrome. Ataxia is also seen in Benedikt's syndrome. Ataxia is seen when red nucleus is involved.

Source:

BD Chaurasia's Human Anatomy, regional and applied, 8th Edition, Page100

questions.text: Which of the following joints does not allow for rotational movements?
questions.solution:
• Rotational movements are caused by pivot joint, which is exemplified by superior and inferior radioulnar joints.
  • The middle radioulnar joint is a fibrous joint and does not cause rotation.
  • Another example of a pivot joint is the Atlantoaxial joint, which is involved in side-to-side movement of the head

Source:

BD Chaurasia's handbook of general anatomy, 4th Edition, Page 57

questions.text: The joint highlighted in the image below is which type of a joint?
questions.solution:
The joint shown above is a primary cartilaginous joint, aka synchondrosis.

Source-

BD Chaurasia's handbook of general anatomy, 4th Edition, Page 57

Grey's Anatomy, The Anatomical Basis of Clinical practice, 41st edition - page 97

questions.text: Which of the following is known as the dangerous area of scalp?
questions.solution:
The loose connective tissue layer is considered the 'danger area' of the scalp.

This is because it contains the emissary veins - these are valveless veins which connect the extracranial veins of the scalp to the intracranial dural venous sinuses. The emissary veins are a potential pathway for the spread of infection from the scalp to the intracranial space.

The scalp consists of five layers. The first three layers are tightly bound together and move as a collective structure.


Layers of Scalp

Source:

BD Chaurasia's Handbook of General Anatomy, 4th Edition, Page 171

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presented to the Orthopedics department with the following findings. Her imaging revealed a supracondylar fracture of the humerus. Apart from this finding, which of the following do you expect to see in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical case with supracondylar fracture of the humerus along with the image showing pointing index finger deformity, or benediction hand deformity.

This suggests Anterior interosseous nerve injury, which is the most commonly injured nerve in this fracture.

Deformities of proximal median nerve injury include-

  • Forearm flexors are paralyzed
  • Pronation lost
  • Wrist deviates to ulnar side on flexion as flexor carpi radialis is lost. So flexor carpi ulnaris overacts.
  • Lateral 2/3rd of flexor digitorum profundus is lost, thus flexion of DIP of index and middle finger is lost, causing pointing hand/index finger deformity
  • Flexor digitorum superficialis is paralyzed, leading to loss of flexion at PIP
  • Thenar atrophy
  • Loss of sensation over lateral 3 ½ digits and thenar eminence
  • Ape thumb deformity- opponens polices activity is lost

Source-

BD Chaurasia's Human Anatomy, Regional and Applied, 8th Edition, Volume-1, Page 122

questions.text: What is the test to check the patency of the ulnar and radial arteries called?
questions.solution:
Allen's test is done to check the patency of the ulnar and radial artery.

Pressure is applied on both sides of the wrist and the patient clenches and unclenches the hand till it becomes pale.

The radial artery and ulnar artery are released one after the other and return of color is looked for in the palm.

If color is restored when the pressure is released on that side, the artery on that side is patent.

Finkelstein's test is pain felt on ulnar deviation in De Quervain's Tenosynovitis.

Froment's test is performed to check the functioning of adductor policis (to test ulnar nerve patency).

Egawa test is performed to check the functioning of dorsal interossei.

Source-

BD Chaurasia's Human Anatomy, Regional and Applied, 8th Edition, Volume-1, Page 152

questions.text:
Match the types of cartilage given below with the places they are found in.
1. Epiglottis
2.Costal cartilage
3.intervertebral disc
questions.solution:
The cartilages given above are-

a -> Hyaline cartilage

b -> Elastic cartilage

c -> White fibrous cartilage.

Source-

Inderbir Singh's textbook of human histology, 8th edition, page 55

choices.text: Increased arterial partial pressure of oxygen

questions.text: A 19-year-old male soccer player undergoes an exercise tolerance test to measure his maximal oxygen uptake during exercise. Which of the following changes are most likely to occur during exercise?
questions.solution:
Exercise increases cardiac output and pulmonary blood flow.

Physiologic dead space consists of the anatomic dead space and the alveolar dead space.

In the resting state, the majority of pulmonary blood flow goes to the base of the lungs due to gravity, and therefore alveolar dead space primarily localizes to the lung apices.

During exercise, vasodilation of the pulmonary vessels in the apices occurs. Additionally, the increased right ventricular cardiac output increases pulmonary circulatory pressure, allowing the opening of apical blood vessels that were collapsed at rest.

These processes increase apical lung perfusion, therebydecreasing alveolar dead space and subsequently, physiologic dead space.

Source:

Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology by John E. Hall, Edition 12, Page No. 1031

choices.text: Increased accumulation of mitochondria in subsarcolemmal region
Decreased expression of sarcolemmal Na+/K+ ATPase

questions.text: An investigator is working with a mutant strain of mice that lack a consistent density of sarcolemmal transverse tubules in the skeletal muscle cells. Which of the following is the most likely associated finding as a result of this abnormality?
questions.solution:
The sarcolemma is analogous to the membrane of skeletal and cardiac muscle cells.

Transverse tubules (T tubules) are invaginations of the sarcolemma.

The sarcoplasmic reticulum, which stores the calcium needed for muscle contraction, has enlarged terminal cisterns that are in contact with T tubules at the junction of the A band and I band.

As a result of this coupling between the sarcoplasmic reticulum and T tubules, depolarization of the T tubule leads to calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum.

The binding of calcium to troponin C shifts tropomyosin away from the myosin-binding sites on the actin filament. This shift allows the myosin head to bind to actin, leading to the formation of a cross-bridge with this final step facilitating sarcomere contraction.

The simultaneous release of calcium is required for the synchronized contraction of all sarcomeres within a myocyte and is mediated by the specific spatial relationship of the T tubules to the sarcoplasmic reticulum.

A differential density of T tubules within a skeletal myocyte would, therefore, lead to desynchronized cross-bridge formation.

Source: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology by John E. Hall, Edition 12, Page No. 71

questions.text: Cell bodies of orexigenic neurons are present in:
questions.solution: Neurotransmitters that increase food intake are said to be orexigenic. Neurotransmitters with orexigenic effects include neuropeptide Y, orexin A and orexin B. Orexins are synthesized in neurons located in the lateral hypothalamus. The feeding center is located in the lateral hypothalamus. Ghrelin, a circulating hormone from the stomach acting on the hypothalamus stimulates food intake. In contrast, leptin from adipose tissue acts on the hypothalamus signaling satiety and inhibits food intake.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the effect of antihypertensive drugs on cardiac output and renal blood flow. For comparison, a healthy volunteer is given a placebo and a continuous infusion of para-aminohippuric acid (PAH) to achieve a plasma concentration of 0.02 mg/ml. His urinary flow rate is 1.5 ml/min and the urinary concentration of PAH is measured to be 8 mg/ml. His hematocrit is 50%. Which of the following values best estimates cardiac output in this volunteer?
questions.solution:
Renal blood flow in a healthy individual is ∼ 20-25% of the cardiac output (CO).

To calculate cardiac output, the renal plasma flow (RPF) and renal blood flow (RBF) will first need to be determined.

RPF = (UPAH x Urine flow rate)/PPAH, where UPAH = urine concentration of para-aminohippuric acid (PAH) and PPAH = plasma concentration of PAH.

Thus, RPF = 8 x 1.5/0.02 = 600 ml/min.

Next, RBF = RPF/(1 - Hct); RBF = 600/(1 - 0.5) = 1.2 L/min.

Finally, the kidneys receive 20-25% of cardiac output, so that this person's CO is 4.8-6.0 L/min (1.2 L/min/0.25 or 1.2/0.20 = 4.8 or 6.0 L/min, respectively).

Source: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology by John E. Hall, Edition 12, Page No. 323

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She is doing well. She is 168 cm tall and weighs 75 kg; BMI is 27 kg/m2. Her BMI had previously been stable at 24 kg/m2. The patient states that she has had decreased appetite over the past month. The patient's change in appetite is most likely mediated by which of the following?
questions.solution:
An increase in adipose tissue beyond the body fat 'setpoint' causes an increase in the serum concentration of leptin, the 'satiety hormone.'

Decreased hypothalamic neuropeptide Y (NPY) due to an increase in leptin serum concentration is the most likely explanation for this patient's decreased appetite.

Leptin, a long-term regulator of appetite, is produced in adipose tissue and inhibits hunger by counteracting the effect of NPY, which in turn is a potent stimulator of hunger.

A loss of this effect (e.g., due to leptin insensitivity) leads to unopposed appetite, resulting in obesity.

Source: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology by John E. Hall, Edition 12, Page No. 881

choices.text: Increase the serum hydrogen ion concentration
Decrease the proportion of fetal hemoglobin
Increase the arterial partial pressure of carbon dioxide

questions.text: An investigator is studying the effects of tissue hypoxia on skeletal muscles. Skeletal muscle hypoxia is induced by decreasing oxygen delivery to peripheral tissues. Which of the following is most likely to achieve this desired effect?
questions.solution:
Oxygen delivery to the peripheral tissues decreases when hemoglobin binds more strongly to oxygen. This can be achieved if the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve shifts to the left.

A decrease in serum 2,3-bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG) concentration decreases oxygen availability in the peripheral tissues. 2,3-BPG binds hemoglobin and stabilizes it in its low oxygen affinity state, which increases oxygen unloading. Therefore, decreased availability of this molecule will lead to less unloading of oxygen and induce tissue hypoxia.

Factors that shift the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve to the left include-

  • Decreased 2,3 BPG concentration
  • Decreased H+ concentration (Increased pH)
  • Increased proportion of fetal hemoglobin
  • Decreased temperature
  • Decreased arterial partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PCO2)

Source: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology by John E. Hall, Edition 12, Page No. 1031

questions.text: An investigator develops a new drug that decreases the number of voltage-gated potassium channels in cardiac muscle cell membranes. Which of the following is the most likely effect of this drug on the myocardial action potential?
questions.solution:
A decreased number of voltage-gated K+ channels results in a decreased K+ outflow.

Repolarization of the cardiac myocyte is dependant on the efflux of K+ from the cell.

Once the peak of the action potential (∼ +30 mV) is reached, voltage-gated K+ channels will open, causing the cell membrane potential to repolarize towards the resting potential of K+ (∼ -70 mV to -90 mV).

Blockade of voltage-gated K+ channels will therefore delay repolarization.

Source: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology by John E. Hall, Edition 12, Page No. 89

questions.text: An infant boy has repeatedly experienced hypoglycemia and seizures. On your exam, decreased muscle tone, growth retardation, and hepatomegaly are noted. The patient has normal serum lactate. A liver biopsy is shown in the image. Further biochemical testing reveals abundant glycogen with abnormally short outer chains. Which of the following enzymes is most likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient is suffering from deficiency of alpha-1,6-glucosidase (glycogen debranching enzyme).

The vignette described is seen in type III glycogen storage disease (Cori disease), which is due to an inability to debranch glycogen.

Patients present with hepatomegaly and hypoglycemia. Biochemical analysis will show abnormal short outer glycogen chains. The liver biopsy specimen shows hepatocytes distended with large stores of glycogen.


Source: Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students, by DM Vasudevan, 9th Edition, Page Number 147

questions.text: A 29-year-old male presents to the family physician concerned over the blue-black discoloration of her sclera and skin as well as black stains on his underwear. The incomplete breakdown of which of the following amino acids is responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
The patient has a diagnosis of alkaptonuria based on the discoloration of her skin and sclera and the change in color of the urine in her underwear at the end of the day. Alkaptonuria is due to the incomplete breakdown of tyrosine.

Alkaptonuria is due to the inability to break down homogentisic acid, the breakdown products of tyrosine and phenylalanine metabolism, resulting from a deficiency of homogentisate oxidase.

Patients typically have the onset of symptoms before the 3rd decade of life due to the accumulation of homogentisic acid.

They will present with arthritis due to accumulation within the cartilage resulting in a black discoloration of the cartilage. Similarly, the skin and sclera discolor and the urine discolors upon sitting in open air due to the oxidizing effect of oxygen or upon the addition of an oxidizing agent to the urine.

Source: Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students, by DM Vasudevan, 9th Edition, Page Number 307

questions.text: Which of the following components were most likely transferred from HDL to VLDL particles to enable triglyceride hydrolysis?
questions.solution:
The protein that is transferred between lipoprotein particles and serves to promote triglyceride hydrolysis is most likely ApoC-II, which activates lipoprotein lipase.

Apolipoproteins are a class of particles that transport fatty acids and cholesterol throughout the body. They are composed of lipid cores that are surrounded by an apoproteins (containing phospholipid layer).

Each class of apolipoprotein contains a unique collection of apoproteins, which. Importantly, d

Different classes of apolipoprotein particles contain different proteins which allows them to support the proper distribution and metabolism of lipids.

HDL particles contain-

  • ApoA-1, which activates lecithin cholesterol acyltransferase.
  • ApoC-II, which is donated to VLDL particles and activates lipoprotein lipase.

LDL particles have ApoB-100 which mediates endocytosis of LDL by binding to LDL receptors on liver and tissues.

ApoE is donated from HDL to VLDL and mediates uptake by the liver.

Source: Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students, by DM Vasudevan, 9th Edition, Page Number 220

questions.text: A 1-year-old girl is brought to the clinic with a 6-month history of diarrhea. Her stools are foul-smelling and nonbloody. There is no family history of serious illness. She is at the 15th percentile for height and 5th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows abdominal distension. Her serum triglyceride concentration is 5 mg/dL. Genetic analysis shows a mutation in the gene that encodes microsomal triglyceride transfer protein. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has Hereditary Abetalipoproteinemia.

  • It is a rare, autosomal recessive condition.
  • Caused by a mutation in the gene that encodes microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTTP).
  • This results in the absence of production of apolipoprotein B (apo B). Accordingly, no lipoproteins that contain apo B (e.g., chylomicrons, LDL, VLDL) are present in serum, which leads to fat malabsorption.
  • Manifestations of this condition include fat malabsorption (which causes steatorrhea and failure to thrive), hepatomegaly (which causes abdominal distension), and very low or absent serum lipid concentrations.
  • Because dietary intake of fats exacerbates hereditary abetalipoproteinemia, treatment includes a low-fat diet with restriction of long-chain fatty acids.
  • Patients also require supplementation with fat-soluble vitamins.

Source: Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students, by DM Vasudevan, 9th Edition, Page Number 100

questions.text: Radiation caused minor damage to the DNA of the exposed skin by severing covalent bonds between the nitrogenous bases and the core ribose leaving several apurinic/apyrimidinic sites. Damaged cells would most likely repair these sites by which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
In the case of an apurinic/apyrimidinic site secondary to cleavage of the bond between the nucleotide and the ribose sugar, the cell uses base excision repair to repair this site.

Radiation can cause a wide variety of DNA damage such as phosphodiester cleavage, double-stranded DNA breaks, and cleavage of the bond between the nucleotide and the ribose sugar leaving an apurinic/apyrimidinic site.

Base excision repair (BER) is utilized by the cell to correct damage done to DNA when a nucleotide is missing from the sugar-phophate backbone or when spontaneous deamination converts a cytosine residue to a uracil residue.

The BER pathway starts off with a DNA glycosylase recognizing and removing the damaged base.

An apurinic/apyrimidinic endonuclease cleaves the backbone, removing the remaining sugar fragment.

The gap is then filled with the cell's DNA replication machinery - DNA polymerase and ligase.

Other Options:

Option A: Nucleotide excision repair is involved in repairing DNA helix-distorting damage.

Option C: Mismatch repair is involved in repairing insertions and deletions of bases during DNA replication.

Option D: Non-homologous end joining and homologous recombination are involved in repairing double stranded breaks.


Source: Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students, by DM Vasudevan, 9th Edition, Page Number 575

questions.text: A researcher creates antibodies that are highly specific to identify amino acid sequences in individuals suspected of having Creutzfeld-Jacob disease (CJD). Which of the following tests would be most helpful in identifying these individuals?
questions.solution:
The western blot is a commonly used diagnostic technique that detects disease-specific proteins using antibodies targeted to those proteins.

This investigator is attempting to diagnose a disease (CJD) based on the presence of a specific amino acid sequence on a specific protein. The ideal test in this case would be a western blot.

Western blots are diagnostic and investigative tools that can detect the presence of disease-specific proteins. They are performed by first applying a tissue sample to a nitrocellulose membrane, then detecting the presence of specific proteins in that tissue sample using highly specific antibodies.

This technique is used to diagnose HIV, some forms of Lyme disease, and hepatitis B.


Source: Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students, by DM Vasudevan, 9th Edition, Page Number 654

questions.text: A 2-month-old boy presents with poor weight gain and physical exam reveals hepatosplenomegaly. A bone marrow biopsy is shown in image. Which of the following substances will most likely accumulate in this patient?
questions.solution:
Niemann-Pick disease is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a defect in sphingomyelinase.

It is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner and has increased risk in Ashkenazi Jewish patients. Patients with this disease will accumulate sphingomyelin in cells resulting in foamy histiocytes and general cell dysfunction.

Patients will present with neonatal-onset failure to thrive, neurodegeneration, and death within the first 3 years of life. A physical exam will reveal hepatosplenomegaly, pallor due to anemia, and cherry-red spots on the macula.

Image shows a slide with foamy histiocytes characteristically seen in Niemann-Pick disease. They have a very clear cytoplasm with a loculated appearance.

Other Options:

Option A: Ceramide trihexose accumulates in Fabry disease, which would present with peripheral neuropathy and angiokeratomas. It does not usually present with failure to thrive though it can also be associated with cardiovascular disease in the newborn period.

Option B: Galactocerebroside would accumulate in Krabbe disease, which presents with hyperactive reflexes, optic atrophy, and developmental delay; however, the characteristic finding in this disease is globoid cells, which are large multinucleated cells that contain PAS-positive inclusions.

Option C: Tay-Sachs does not present with hepatosplenomegaly and would also have onion skin lysosomes rather than foamy histiocytes. There is accumulation of GM2 ganglioside.

Source: Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students, by DM Vasudevan, 9th Edition, Page Number

questions.text: On microscopic examination, the biopsy sample shows uniform squamous cells in layers in bronchus of a patient. Which of the following best describes the histologic finding seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Metaplasia is a non-neoplastic and reversible transformation of a mature cell type into another cell type that is not native to that specific region.

This usually occurs as a protective mechanism to adapt to chronic irritation or cell injury.

The normal bronchial epithelium is composed of pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium with numerous mucus-secreting goblet cells.

The stratified squamous epithelium seen on this patient's biopsy is not native to the bronchial tree and is a sign of metaplastic stem cell reprogramming (squamous metaplasia), most likely due to chronic smoking.

Other examples of metaplasia are Barrett esophagus (due to chronic exposure to gastric acid) and myositis ossificans.

If chronic irritation persists, dysplastic changes (e.g., cellular atypia, numerous mitotic figures, increased nucleus: cytoplamic ratio) changes can occur in metaplastic tissue.

Hyperplasia is the increase in the number of cells.


Source: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 31

questions.text: A patient mentions that while he was cooking 5 days ago, he accidentally cut himself. Which of the following can be expected on histopathological examination of the wounded area?
questions.solution:
The patient has a non-infected wound with healthy granulation tissue, which demonstrates the deposition of type III collagen around 5 days after injury.


Source: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 57

questions.text: A 29-year-old sexually active woman with multiple partners and intermittently uses condoms for contraception, comes to clinic. Results from a routine pap smear are shown. The cellular changes seen are attributable to?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is cervical dysplasia secondary to infection with human papilloma virus (HPV).

HPV is a non-enveloped DNA virus that is sexually transmitted. Certain HPV subtypes (6 and 11) are associated with anogenital warts while other subtypes (16, 18, 31, 33) can become neoplastic. The latter subtypes are oncogenic because they produce the proteins E6 and E7. These proteins inhibit tumor suppressors p53 and Rb, respectively.

Inhibition of tumor suppressors leads to cervical intraepithelial neoplasia, which can either resolve spontaneously or eventually progress to squamous cell carcinoma.

The most important risk factor for HPV infection is having multiple sexual partners. In this patient, the presence of enlarged nuclei and hyperchromatic cells on routine pap smear indicates a premalignant transformation of squamous cells on the surface of the cervix.

Other Options:

Option B: p53 is a tumor suppressor. Inhibition of p53 is associated with multiple neoplasms but activation of p53 would not be oncogenic.

Option C: Rb is a tumor suppressor. HPV infection with oncogenic HPV subtypes can inhibit Rb via the E7 protein. Activation of Rb would not be oncogenic.

Option D: K-Ras is a member of the RAS family of oncogenes. Activating mutations in RAS genes are associated with multiple neoplasms including leukemia, colon cancer, pancreatic cancer, and lung cancer.

Source: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 189

questions.text:
A 14-year-old boy presents with swelling on his left tibia. An X-ray of the leg shows a destructive process, with indistinct borders and an 'onion-skin' pattern of periosteal bone. Histologic examination reveals uniform small round, dark blue nuclei (shown in the image).

Immunohistochemistry for CD 99 is positive and LCA negative. Which of the following is the most likely tumor?
questions.solution: Ewing sarcoma (EWS) is an uncommon malignant bone tumor composed of small, uniform, round cells. It represents only 5% of all bone tumors and is found in children and adolescents. EWS is thought to arise from primitive marrow elements or immature mesenchymal cells. These tumor cells are positive for immunohistochemistry of CD 99

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with lung cancer comes with a seizure. Laboratory studies show a serum sodium concentration of 119 mEq/L and glucose concentration of 102 mg/dL. Microscopic examination of this mass is most likely to confirm which of the following diagnoses?
questions.solution:
Hyponatremia in a smoker with weight loss and persistent cough suggests a paraneoplastic syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH).

Microscopic examination of this hilar density is most likely to reveal a small cell lung carcinoma (SCLC). SIADH is one of the common paraneoplastic syndromes associated with SCLC; others include Cushing syndrome and Lambert-Eaton syndrome.

Other Options:

Option A: Although squamous cell lung carcinoma is the most common lung cancer in smokers and can also manifest with a central mass, it is not typically associated with SIADH. Instead, it causes hypercalcemia due to the release of parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP).

Option C: Large cell lung carcinoma is unlikely since it typically has peripheral localization and is not associated with SIADH. In some cases, it may cause paraneoplastic secretion of G-CSF or gynecomastia due to secretion of the beta subunit of β-HCG.

Option D: A bronchial carcinoid tumor is unlikely in this patient because it is not associated with SIADH. Instead, it can cause carcinoid syndrome (due to ectopic serotonin secretion).

Source: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 189

questions.text: A mother brings her 10-year-old girl with difficulty in balance and has been falling more than usual. She also complains of a rash on her face. Patient's alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) level is found to be elevated. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with ataxia-telangiectasia.

Ataxia-telangiectasia (AT) is a B and T cell immunodeficiency caused by defects in the ATM gene on chromosome 11 which codes for DNA repair enzymes. This makes cells hypersensitive to ionizing radiation and results in the characteristic triad of -

  • Cerebellar defects - causing difficulty in balance
  • Spider angiomas (telangiectasias)
  • IgA deficiency

Patients may also experience recurrent pulmonary infections and an increased risk of malignancy due to lack of DNA repair. On labs, an increased alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is often seen.

Other Options:

Option A: Defects in cellular transport do not cause AT.

Option B: Defects in cell surface receptors are not observed in AT. Rather, they are seen in severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID), which is characterized by defective IL-2 receptors.

Option C: Defects in microtubule function are not observed in AT. Rather, they are seen in Chediak-Higashi syndrome in which there is microtubule dysfunction in phagosome-lysosome functions.

Source: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 168

questions.text: A 39-year-old G1P0 female at 36 weeks gestation will give birth to an infant with the following karyotype. Which of the following will the infant be at an increased risk of developing later in life?
questions.solution:
The karyotype demonstrates trisomy 21. Individuals with Down syndrome have an increased risk of developing ALL (Acute lymphoblastic leukemia).

Down syndrome (DS) is the most common chromosomal disorder and cause of congenital mental retardation. Trisomy 21 is typically due to maternal meiotic nondisjunction occurring primarily in meiosis I but also in meiosis II. Other causes may be due to a Robertsonian translocation and, less commonly, mosaicism.

Patients with trisomy 21 have an increased risk for developing AML (Acute myeloid leukemia)(< 3 y/o), ALL (> 3 y/o), Alzheimer's disease by their fifth decade, Hirschsprung's disease, and duodenal atresia.

Other Options:

Option A: Individuals born with Klinefelter syndrome (47,XXY) have an increased risk of developing testicular neoplasms.

Option B & C: Individuals born with Turner syndrome (45,XO) have an increased risk of developing gonadal blastomas and dysgerminoma ovarian tumors.

Source: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 243

questions.text: On workup of a 43-year-old male, a tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) assay comes back positive. Bone marrow aspirate does not yield a sample due to extensive fibrosis. Which of the following is the first-line agent for the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
This clinical presentation is consistent with hairy cell leukemia; first-line treatment for hairy cell leukemia consists of cladribine, an adenosine deaminase inhibitor.

Hairy cell leukemia -

  • It is an uncommon chronic B cell lymphoproliferative disorder.
  • Typically affects older adults, and is more common in men.
  • Patients commonly present with symptoms related to massive splenomegaly and cytopenias.
  • Diagnosis of hairy cell leukemia is made on the basis of several factors:
  • Recognition of the characteristic hairy leukocyte on blood smear with a 'fried egg' appearance.
  • Bone marrow that cannot be aspirated due to extensive fibrosis.
  • Positive tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) assay.
  • Treatment is indicated for alleviation of symptoms related to splenomegaly and cytopenias. Cladribine is considered first-line therapy.

Image depicts a characteristic circulating hairy leukocyte from a peripheral blood smear. It is a mononuclear cell, usually one to two times the size of a mature lymphocyte, with a cytoplasmic outline that is often indistinct with varying projections.

Source: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 441

choices.text: Decreased platelet aggregation on peripheral blood smear
Increased prothrombin time and partial thromboplastin time
Increased serum von Willebrand factor multimers

questions.text:
A 23-year-old woman presents with a 3-day history of fever and headache. Physical exam reveals diffuse petechiae and conjunctival pallor and selected laboratory results are shown as follows:
Bleeding time: 11 minutes
Platelet count: 68,000/mm^3
Lactate dehydrogenase: 505 U/L
Which of the following would also most likely be true for this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with fever, headache, fatigue, conjunctival pallor, petechiae, an increased bleeding time, and decreased platelets most likely has thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura, which would present with increased serum von Willebrand factor multimers.

Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP)-

  • Caused by a deficiency or inhibition of the ADAMTS13 metalloproteinase, which normally functions to separate von Willebrand factor (vWF) multimers into monomers.
  • In this disorder, the persistence of vWF multimers leads to the formation of microvascular platelet thrombosis and systemic thrombocytopenia since the platelets are consumed in this process.
  • Furthermore, shearing of erythrocytes that travel through these thrombosed vessels leads to a hemolytic anemia.
  • Though most patients do not have all the signs, this disease presents with a classic pentad of -
  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia
  • Acute renal failure
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Fever
  • Neurologic abnormalities

Other Options:

Option A: Decreased platelet aggregation on peripheral blood smear would be seen in Glanzmann thrombasthenia; however, this disease would not present with conjunctival pallor since it does not cause anemia.

Option B: Immune production of anti-platelet antibodies would be seen in idiopathic thrombocytopenia; however, this disease would not present with conjunctival pallor since it does not cause anemia.

Option C: Increased prothrombin time and partial thromboplastin time would be seen in disseminated intravascular coagulation; however, this patient has relatively stable vital signs.

Source: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 441

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with a hot, swollen, and painful knee. He has been treated with long courses of antibiotics for multiple infections. Laboratory tests are obtained with the following results:
PT: Prolonged
aPTT: Prolonged
Bleeding time: Normal
The activity of which of the following circulating factors would most likely be affected by this patient's disorder?
questions.solution:
This patient with chronic antibiotic use and prolonged prothrombin time (PT) and partial thromboplastin time (PTT) with a normal bleeding time most likely has vitamin K deficiency, which would affect the activity of factor C.

Vitamin K is an essential component of an epoxide reductase enzyme that is responsible for proper processing of multiple coagulation cascade factors. Deficiency of this vitamin can therefore lead to disruption of all vitamin K-dependent factors: II, VII, IX, X, protein C, and protein S.

Vitamin K deficiency is more common in newborns, patients with malabsorptive syndromes, and patients who take prolonged courses of antibiotics. Antibiotics can trigger this condition because they kill the gut bacteria that produce vitamin K.

Other Options:

Option A: Factor VIII would be affected by hemophilia; however, this disorder would present with an abnormal PTT but a normal PT.

Option B: Factor XI would be affected by heparin administration; however, there is no indication that heparin was given to this patient.

Option C: Platelet factor 4 can be affected by heparin induced thrombocytopenia; however, this disorder would present with an abnormal bleeding time.

Source: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 441

choices.text: Increase rate of transfusion with additional anti-histaminics

questions.text: What is the most appropriate management of a patient with Transfusion related Acute Lung Injury (TRALI)?
questions.solution:
Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) is a serious and potentially fatal complication of blood product transfusion in which a patient develops rapid onset lung injury and non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema due to activation of immune cells in the lungs.

TRALI favors a 'two hit' hypothesis.

  • The first hit is an exposure that activates endothelial cells in pulmonary capillaries. This 'priming' event has diverse causes, including smoking, sepsis, and shock, and leads to sequestration of neutrophils.
  • The primed neutrophils are then activated by a factor present in the transfused blood product, which constitutes the second hit. By far the most common antibodies associated with TRALI are those that bind MHC class I antigens.

The typical presentation of TRALI is the sudden development of shortness of breath, severe hypoxemia (O2 saturation <90% in room air), low blood pressure, and fever that develop within 6 hours after transfusion and usually resolve with supportive care within 48 to 96 hours.

Treatment includes stopping transfusion with supportive O2 inhalators and bronchodilators.

TRALI is the most common cause of death after blood transfusion.

Source: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 441

choices.text: Amino acid substitution in the β-globin protein

questions.text:
Hemoglobin: 11.0 g/dL
MCV: 74 μm3
RDW: 14% (N = 13%-15%)
Serum ferritin: 77 ng/mL.
Peripheral blood smear shows small, pale red blood cells. Hemoglobin electrophoresis is normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Laboratory evaluation shows a mild, microcytic anemia with hypochromia, a normal ferritin level, and normal hemoglobin electrophoresis, which indicates α-thalassemia.

This patient's findings are consistent with the minor form of alpha thalassemia, which is caused by two defective alleles of genes that encode α-globin chains (-α/-α or --/αα); cis deletion is common in Asian populations.

  • Deletion of one out of four alleles results in disease that is clinically silent.
  • The deletion of two alleles reduces α-globin levels enough to cause mild symptoms.
  • Deletion of three or four alleles of the α-globin gene causes aberrant hemoglobin formation (i.e., β4 or γ4) that would be visible on hemoglobin electrophoresis and causes more severe clinical symptoms.

Source: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 441

choices.text: Occlusion of the posterior descending artery

questions.text: A 76-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for evaluation of sudden-onset chest pain. Three days after admission, he develops severe shortness of breath. Based on left ventricle autopsy, which of the following most likely contributed to this patient's cause of death?
questions.solution:
The image shows a rupture in the posteromedial papillary muscle. Papillary muscle rupture is life-threatening and can occur 2-7 days after myocardial infarction.

The posterior descending artery (PDA) arises from the right coronary artery (RCA), supplies the posterior aspect of the heart, and provides the only blood supply to the posteromedial papillary muscle.

Occlusion of the PDA or the RCA causing myocardial infarction, can result in ischemic rupture of the posteromedial papillary muscle as seen in this patient.

Clinical manifestations of papillary muscle rupture include sudden-onset hypotension, a holosystolic murmur (due to mitral regurgitation), and symptoms of pulmonary edema (e.g., dyspnea, cough). Severe mitral regurgitation can cause acute heart failure and death.


Source: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 399

choices.text: Smooth muscle cells -- extracellular matrix deposition
Smooth muscle cells -- migration from intima to media

questions.text: In the formation of an atherosclerotic plaque, which of the following pairings is correct?
questions.solution:
In the formation of an atherosclerotic plaque, smooth muscle cells (SMC) are responsible for the deposition of extracellular matrix (ECM) in the intima. SMC proliferation and SMC-mediated ECM deposition are major processes leading to intimal thickening.

There are several mechanisms leading to endothelial dysfunction, including dyslipidemia and inflammation. This dysfunction allows for the deposition of LDL in the intima and the recruitment of monocytes. Factors released by injured endothelial cells and monocytes contribute to SMC migration and proliferation. Combined, these processes lead to the formation of an atheroma (atherosclerotic plaque).

Other Options:

Option A: Macrophages become foam cells following phagocytosis of lipid particles.

Option C: Endothelial cells upregulate vascular cell-adhesion molecules, such as VCAM-1, which allow for leukocyte adhesion to the injured vascular wall, ultimately facilitating diapedesis.

Option D: Smooth muscle cells migrate from the media to the intima.

Source: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 399

questions.text: A mother brings her 5-year-old son with swollen face, after a honey colored rash which resolved 2 weeks ago. Urinalysis which demonstrates hematuria and red blood cell casts. Which of the following light microscopy images is most likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with acute poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (APSGN) which demonstrates enlarged glomeruli and hypercellular neutrophils as seen in Option A.

APSGN is an inflammatory process causing nephritic syndrome characterized by hematuria and red blood cell casts on urinalysis. It is most frequently seen in children and causes peripheral and periorbital edema, dark urine, and hypertension. It is caused by a type III, immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity reaction following a streptococcal infection. On light microscopy(LM) hypercellularity and enlarged glomeruli are observed.

Other Options:

Option B: Figure B demonstrates the LM findings of rapidly progressive (crescentic) glomerulonephritis (RPGN).

Option C: Figure C demonstrates the LM findings of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis which is more common in IV drug abusers, African Americans, and Hispanics.

Option D: Figure D demonstrates the LM findings of a normal glomerulus.

Source: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 549

questions.text: A patient with a history of hypertension presents with hematuria and abdominal discomfort. Ultrasound reveals large, bilateral cysts in all regions of the kidney. The patient's disease is most commonly associated with?
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms and imaging findings are suggestive of adult polycystic kidney disease, or autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). ADPKD is associated with Berry aneurysms in the circle of Willis in 10-15% of patients.

ADPCKD usually presents in the 3rd or 4th decade of life. It is marked by multiple, large, bilateral cysts in all regions of the kidney. Cysts may also occur in the liver (30%), pancreas and spleen. Associated complications include berry aneurysm, mitral valve prolapse (MVP), and diverticulosis. Patients are at increased risk for renal cell carcinoma.

Other Options:

Option A: Aortic stenosis is the narrowing of the aortic valve, often due to calcification. It is not associated with ADPKD.

Option B: Berger's disease, or IgA nephropathy, is caused by IgA deposition in glomeruli. It is not associated with ADPKD.

Option C: ADKPD is not associated with diabetes mellitus.

Source: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 549

questions.text: An endoscopy finds disease involvement in the terminal ileum, noting that the disease process is patchy with normal intervening mucosa. The entire wall of the region is thickened and inflamed, which may directly lead to formation of?
questions.solution:
Fistulas due to transmural inflammation are a common feature of Crohn's disease. Involvement may be throughout the gastrointestinal system but commonly near the terminal ileum. Common symptoms include malaise, diarrhea, weight loss, and abdominal discomfort.

Though the exact mechanism is still under investigation, it is believed that the combination of an impaired barrier function of epithelial cells and the subsequent ability for bacterial components to access immune cells contributes to the disease. The result is inflammation throughout the thickness of the gastrointestinal tissue (transmural inflammation). This transmural inflammation contributes to many of the endoscopic findings - ulcers, strictures, and fistulas.

Other Options:

Option B: Toxic megacolon would be more consistent with ulcerative colitis

Option C: Stricture formation (narrowing of the lumen), not widening of the lumen, is more consistent with Crohn's disease.

Option D: Plummer-Vinson syndrome (esophageal webs, iron-deficiency, and glottitis) is not consistent with Crohn's disease.

Source: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 583

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presents with watery diarrhea for the last 3 weeks. She denies abdominal pain or rash. A basic metabolic profile is notable for the following: Na: 127 mEq/L; K 2.1 mEq/L; Glucose 98 mg/dL. Octreotide was started with significant improvement in symptoms and laboratory values. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient had watery diarrhea and significant hypokalemia which improved with octreotide. Of the given choices, this is consistent with a VIPoma.

VIPoma is a neoplasm that produces ectopic vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP).

VIP is normally a stimulator of gastric motility and secretion.

Massive overproduction of VIP leads to secretory diarrhea, achlorhydria, hypokalemia, and normal anion gap metabolic acidosis.

The majority of VIPomas are located in the pancreas.

The diagnosis of VIPoma is confirmed via elevated serum VIP.

Treatment can involve surgical resection and/or octreotide administration.

Other Options:

Option B: Glucagonoma usually presents with rash (necrolytic migratory erthema) and hyperglycemia.

Option C: Somatostatinoma presents with steatorrhea and diabetes.

Option D: Insulinoma presents with hypoglycemia.

Source: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 583

questions.text: A three-year-old child presents with rapid jerking movements of his eyes and contractions in his legs. The exam is also remarkable for hypertension and an irregular abdominal mass that crosses the midline. The mass is biopsied and the histological findings are shown in the image. Which of the following is most likely associated with this child's disease?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis for this patient is neuroblastoma, which classically presents with opsoclonus-myoclonus (dancing eyes/feet) in a child with an abdominal mass. Neuroblastoma is associated with mutations in the N-myc gene.

In the clinical vignette, the initial clues of fatigue and movement abnormalities may raise suspicion for an intracranial neurologic problem. Therefore, the additional presence of an abdominal mass and hypertension are important clues to identify neuroblastoma. While there are many different etiologies of an 'abdominal mass,' this finding in a young child should raise suspicion for neuroblastoma as it is the most common extracranial solid tumor in children. Neuroblastoma may be easily confused with nephroblastoma, also known as Wilm's tumor, which also presents with an abdominal mass and hypertension. However, nephroblastoma does not present with opsoclonus-myoclonus (the eye jerking and leg contractions).

The image shows a biopsy demonstrating Homer-Wright rosettes, the characteristic histologic finding in neuroblastoma.

Other Options:

Option B: WAGR syndrome is a genetic syndrome comprised of Wilm's tumor, aniridia (absence of the iris), genitourinary abnormalities, and mental retardation. Nephroblastoma, also known as Wilm's tumor, is a common childhood cancer that may also present with an abdominal mass but is not associated with the opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome.

Option C: Mutation of the Rb gene is involved in the development of retinoblastoma. This can present as a white mass within the eye.

Option D: Mutation of the RET gene is involved in the development of MEN 2A and 2B. These disorders present with multiple endocrine tumors such as medullary thyroid carcinoma and pheochromocytoma.

Source: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 749

questions.text: A radiograph of the 12-year old's right leg is shown. Biopsy of the lesion demonstrates sheets of monotonous small round blue cells with minimal cytoplasm. Which of the following genetic mutations is most likely associated with this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
In this pediatric patient with a small round blue cell tumor arising from the femoral diaphysis, the most likely diagnosis is Ewing sarcoma. Ewing sarcoma is caused by a t(11;22) translocation (causes a EWS-FLI fusion protein).

Ewing sarcoma is a tumor of neuroectodermal origin that typically affects males who are less than 15 years old. It is the second most common bone tumor in children after osteosarcoma. It typically arises in the diaphysis of long bones (e.g., femur, tibia, and humerus) and presents with localized pain and fever. WBC and ESR may be elevated. On radiographic imaging, a large destructive lesion will be seen in the diaphysis of a long bone. Concentric layers of new bone growth can lead to an 'onion skinning' or 'sunburst' appearance on radiograph. Histologically, Ewing sarcoma consists of sheets of monotonous small round blue cells. Ewing sarcoma is a very aggressive tumor and often metastasizes early; however, it is often treatable and responsive to chemotherapy.

Radiograph shows an anterior-posterior view of the distal femoral diaphysis with periosteal reaction leading to the classic 'onion skinning' appearance.

Other Options:

Option A: t(8;14) is associated with Burkitt lymphoma, a form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma seen in the pediatric population. It presents as a jaw mass in the endemic form and as an abdominal mass in the sporadic form.

Option C: APC is a tumor suppressor gene and inactivation of APC is associated with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP). FAP is associated with a dramatically increased risk of colon polyps and colorectal cancer.

Option D: TP53 is a tumor suppressor gene and inactivation of TP53 is found in Li-Fraumeni syndrome. Li-Fraumeni syndrome is associated with an increased risk of multiple tumors including breast cancer, osteosarcoma, and soft tissue sarcoma.

Source: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 797

questions.text: Which of the following is not a Selective COX-2 inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, meloxicam is not a selective COX-2 inhibitor.

Selective COX-2 inhibitors:

Mechanism of action:

Reversible selective inhibition of COX-2 with almost no inhibition of COX-1. COX-2 is found in cells that mediate inflammation and pain (e.g., macrophages, leukocytes), cells that control vasodilation (vascular endothelial cells).

Effects:

  • Analgesic and anti-inflammatory
  • Advantages in comparison to nonselective NSAIDs
  • No antiplatelet effect: platelets only possess COX-1 and are therefore not targeted by selective COX-2 inhibitors. This means that the activity of thromboxane A2 (TXA2) is not interrupted (TXA2 normally promotes platelet aggregation).
  • Gastric mucosal cells express mostly COX-1, which is involved in maintaining a healthy gastric mucosa, so there are minimal gastrointestinal side effects and a lower risk of gastric ulcers.

Side effects:

  • Increased risk of thrombosis, MI, and/or stroke
  • Sulfa drug allergic reaction
  • Renal side effects in at-risk patients
  • Deterioration of chronic renal failure
  • Worsening of hypertension

Source: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 209

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of difficulty walking, slurred speech, and progressive drowsiness. There is diffuse hypotonia and decreased deep tendon reflexes. Administration of a drug that acts as a competitive antagonist at which of the following receptors is most likely to reverse this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Benzodiazepine overdose typically manifests with a sedative-hypnotic toxidrome, as seen in this patient. GABA-A receptor antagonists (ex- flumazenil) would effectively reverse the patient's symptoms.

Benzodiazepines are indirect GABA-A agonists. They increase the affinity of GABA to bind to GABA-A receptors. Increased GABA action increases the frequency with which chloride channels open, which leads to hyperpolarization of the postsynaptic neuronal membrane and thus decreased neuronal excitability.

Source: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 463

choices.text: Cannot be calculated, as bioavailability is not known

questions.text: On diagnosis of pulmonary embolism, IV heparin is initiated. If the volume of distribution of heparin is equivalent to 60 mL/kg and the target peak plasma concentration is 0.5 units/mL, which of the following is the most appropriate loading dose for this patient if weight is 50kg?
questions.solution:
Loading dose is equal to (Cp x Vd) / F, where Cp = peak plasma concentration in units/mL, Vd = volume of distribution (only the total volume), and F = bioavailability.

In this patient, the bioavailability of heparin is 1 as it is an intravenous medication.

This yields a loading dose of (0.5 units/mL x 3,000 mL)/1 = 1,500 units.

Source: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 15

questions.text: Which of the following is not a Hit & Run drug?
questions.solution:
Hit & Run drugs continue to produce action even after complete elimination of the drug.

It occurs due to irreversible binding of the drug to target receptor, by covalent bond.

In such drugs, monitoring of plasma levels is of no value.

Examples of such drugs are:

  1. MAO inhibitors (selegiline)
  2. Proton pump inhibitors (omeprazole)
  3. Organophosphates
  4. Guanethidine
  5. Reserpine
  6. Aspirin

Source: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 92

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman with a history of Hodgkin's lymphoma undergoes standard chemotherapy and radiation therapy and is disease-free at six months. Shortly thereafter, she develops subacute shortness of breath; a CT scan of her chest is obtained as in image.

Which of the following is the mechanism of the medication involved?
questions.solution:
The CT scan shows pulmonary fibrosis as evidenced by the honeycombing of the lung seen.
This patient underwent chemotherapy for treatment of Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL), which is most commonly ABVD (Adriamycin, bleomycin, vinblastine, and dacarbazine).

Bleomycin, which works through creation of DNA strand breaks (and likely also through free radical generation) has the known and feared side effect of pulmonary fibrosis. It most commonly presents 1-6 months following treatment with bleomycin. Glucocorticoids can be used to alleviate symptoms.

Source: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 913

questions.text: A diagnosis of actinic keratosis is made and treatment with 5-fluorouracil is begun. This drug most likely acts on which of the following labeled parts of the cell cycle?
questions.solution:
In the S phase of the cell cycle, DNA replication occurs. Drugs which act specifically during this stage of the cell cycle and inhibit DNA synthesis include -

  • Pyrimidine analogs (e.g., 5-fluorouracil, capecitabine, cytarabine)
  • Purine analogs (e.g., azathioprine, cladribine)
  • Folate analogs (e.g., methotrexate)
  • Hydroxyurea

5-Fluorouracil decreases the synthesis of deoxythymidine monophosphate (a nucleotide) by inhibiting thymidylate synthase.

Source: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 913

questions.text: Which drug is used as rescue therapy in treating Parkinson's disease off phase?
questions.solution:
After long-term treatment with Levodopa (first-line therapy for Parkinson's disease), patients may develop on-off period. During the off phase they may be treated with apomorphine as a 'rescue' medication.

Apomorphine is a non-ergot dopamine agonist. It is given as a rapidly acting, subcutaneous injectable drug.

Source: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 452

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy who is being treated with phenytoin. On physical examination of the mouth and oropharynx, the physician notes the following image. Which of the following is associated with the pathophysiology?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with phenytoin-induced gingival hyperplasia. Phenytoin-induced gingival hyperplasia is associated with increased expression of platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF).

The side effects of PHENYTOIN include -

  • P-450 interactions
  • Hirsutism
  • Enlarged gums
  • Nystagmus, diplopia
  • Yellowing/browning of skin
  • Teratogenicity - fetal hydantoin syndrome
  • Osteomalacia
  • Interference with folic acid absorption leading to megaloblastic anemia
  • Neuropathies

Source: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 438

questions.text: A 53-year-old man, Munna has hyperlipidemia comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Labs show elevated total cholesterol and triglyceride concentrations. A drug that activates the PPAR-alpha is added to his existing therapy. This patient is most likely to develop which of the following drug-related adverse effects?
questions.solution:
Fibrates induce HDL synthesis through PPAR-alpha activation.

Fibrates can potentially cause myopathy as an adverse effect.

  • Reddish-brown discoloration of the urine could indicate myoglobinuria, which can be seen in myopathy or rhabdomyolysis.
  • When combined with statins, which can also independently cause myopathy, the risk of myoglobinuria is even higher. This risk is especially high because fibrates inhibit CYP3A4, the isoenzyme that metabolizes most statins in the cytochrome P450 metabolic pathway, and thus increase the statin concentration.

Source: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 682

questions.text: Two weeks after starting chemotherapy with etoposide, a 66-year-old man with small cell lung cancer comes to the physician because of persistent nausea and vomiting. His symptoms improved significantly after the administration of metoclopramide. This patient's symptoms were most likely due to the effect of chemotherapy on which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Chemotherapy induces nausea by acting on the chemoreceptor trigger zone, which responds to certain chemicals in the blood. Metoclopramide is a dopamine receptor antagonist that is especially effective for chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting.

The area postrema is an area of the medulla that contains the chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ) and is one of the primary sites involved in chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting, along with the nucleus tractus solitarius. The area postrema of the brainstem has fenestrated capillaries, which allows input from substances in the blood such as drugs (e.g., chemotherapy) and/or hormones. Metoclopramide is a D2 dopamine receptor antagonist that acts primarily by inhibiting the vomiting centers of the area postrema.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K. D. Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 705

questions.text: Treatment with high-dose continuous inhaled albuterol has begun. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following adverse effects?
questions.solution:
Hypokalemia is a common adverse effect of continuous albuterol therapy. It is caused by β2-agonist stimulation of the Na+/K+-ATPase, which leads to an intracellular K+ shift. Additionally, β2-mediated stimulation of the liver elevates cAMP levels, thereby increasing glycogenolysis and hyperglycemia. Hyperglycemia stimulates insulin secretion, which also activates the Na+/K+-ATPase and further potentiates the intracellular K+ shift. Hypokalemia can cause EKG changes, such as T wave flattening, ST depression, and U waves.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K. D. Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 237

questions.text: Sheela presented to the Dermatology OPD with the following lesions on the extensor surfaces of her arms and legs, which were white, scaly, and associated with pruritus. On rubbing the scales off, red spots of pinpoint hemorrhage were observed on the lesions. Further, after trauma, new skin lesions similar to these are also known to appear on previously unaffected skin. Which of the following is not preferred for the management of this dermatologic condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette describes psoriasis. The appearance of pinpoint hemorrhage on lesions is called the Auspitz sign, and new lesions on unaffected skin is called Koebner's phenomenon.

Oral glucocorticoids are generally not preferred in psoriasis due to the potential development of pustular psoriasis when discontinued.

Other options

The topical vitamin D analog is calcipotriol. It suppresses proliferation and enhances the differentiation of keratinocytes. Because of the rapid metabolism of percutaneously absorbed calcipotriol, hypercalcemia does not develop.

Tazarotene is a topical retinoid. It also exerts antiproliferative and anti-inflammatory effects.

Apremilast is a new oral phosphodiesterase inhibitor. It is approved for both psoriases as well as psoriatic arthritis.

Reference- Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K. D. Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 951

questions.text: A patient with CHF was started on an inotrope which has the following mechanism of action: However, due to a dosing error, the patient develops bradycardia and syncope. His ECG shows an AV block. What is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows the Na-K pump, which is blocked by digoxin. Its toxicity can cause AV block. The drug of choice for AV block due to vagal overactivity, such as digoxin toxicity, inferior wall MI, and sinus arrest, is Atropine.

Atropine abbreviates A-V node ERP and increases conduction velocity in a bundle of His.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K. D. Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 582

questions.text: Bhanumati is a 69-year-old lady on treatment for chronic congestive heart failure. She is on tablet metoprolol, which was titrated to its maximum dose. She has current active complaints of palpitations. On examination, her resting HR is 100bpm and her BP is 140/90 mm of Hg. Her ECG shows sinus tachycardia and her ECHO shows an EF of 32%. Thus, according to the guidelines, she is prescribed Ivabradine. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Ivabradine is a pure bradycardia-producing antianginal drug that has been recently approved for use in stable grade II to IV heart failure patients who are in sinus rhythm and have a heart rate >70 per min with systolic dysfunction (ER <35%). It works by slowing the heart and improving ventricular filling. Ivabradine is specifically indicated for patients with contraindications to beta-blockers or in those who do not achieve a heart rate reduction of <75/min with an adequate dose of beta-blocker alone. It is given in addition to standard therapy with ACE inhibitors, diuretics, aldosterone antagonists, etc., and has been shown to decrease the composite endpoints of hospitalization and cardiovascular mortality (SHIFT trial 2010). However, it lacks the cardioprotective property of beta blockers.

BNP analogues include Neseritide and calcium sensitizers include Levosimendan.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K. D. Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 568.

choices.text: These two medications cannot be administered concurrently
Double the dose and check for nephrotoxicity

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with IBD was to be switched on to a maintenance regimen. For this, he was prescribed Azathioprine. The patient informs the doctor that he has been taking medication for a sudden and severe swelling in his great toe, which has progressed to chronicity. The doctor finds that this drug inhibits the Xanthine Oxidase enzyme and thus considers changing the dose of Azathioprine. What change does he need to make?
questions.solution:
Azathioprine is a purine analogue that gets converted to its active metabolite, 6-MP. It does not have a marked anticancer effect but is a good immunomodulator owing to its selective uptake in immune cells. It primarily suppresses CMI and has a role in RA, IBD, and the prevention of graft rejection, especially when a dose reduction of cyclosporine is needed.

Allopurinol and oxypurinol are xanthine oxidase inhibitors and are the first lines for the management of chronic gout.

Azathioprine and 6-MP are oxidized by xanthine oxidase and their metabolism is inhibited by allopurinol; the dose has to be reduced to 1⁄4-1⁄2 if allopurinol is given concurrently.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K. D. Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 922.

questions.text: A farmer rearing sheep presented with complaints of fever and weakness for the last one month. There is generalized lymphadenopathy. There was also an associated hepatomegaly biopsy of the liver that showed non-caseating granuloma. There are most likely due to infection with:
questions.solution:
History of contact with sheep and clinical features of weakness, fever, lymphadenopathy with non-Caseating granuloma signifies Brucellosis.

Brucella melitensis is the most pathogenic and most common cause of crucial losses and usually infects sheep, goats, and camels.

Brucella canis usually infects dogs.

Brucella abortus-cattle or buffalo.

Brucella suis-swine

No man-to-man transmission occurs.

Clinical features of brucellosis

fever with profuse weight, especially at night. If untreated fever follows the undulating pattern, i.e. fever → afebrile period → fever.

Fever is associated with musculoskeletal symptoms, i.e., pain.

Septic arthritis

Osteomyelitis commonly affects the lumbar and lower thoracic vertebrae.

Neurological involvement with depression and lethargy

Endocarditis (MC in the aortic valve).

Reference: harrison edition 17 p974

questions.text: The patient had a louse bite. Two weeks later, he comes back with complaints of chills and a fever. He had rashes all over his body and was delirious at the time of presentation to the hospital and subsequently went into a coma A provisional diagnosis of vasculitis due to rickettsial infection was made. Which of the following could be the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The most important point in the given question is 'louse - borne rickettsial infection', which is only one i.e. epidermic typhus which is caused by R. prowazekii.

Epidemic typhus-

Also called as louse-borne typhus or classical type us or goal fever.

Usually seen among military and refugee populations and famine areas.

Humans are the only natural vertebrate hosts.

Vector: body or head louse, not a public louse.

Causative agent: R. Prowazekii

Route of transmission: louse feces are rubbed over abraded skin. So, infection is transmitted from man by the infected louse.

Incubation period: 5 to 15 days.

Clinical features: fever, chills, rash (starts on the trunk and spreads over the limbs, sparing the face, palms, and soles), stupor, and delirium.

Rickettsia may become latent in lymphoid tissue, causing recrudescent typhus or brill-Zinsser disease.

Reference: Ananth Narayan edition 8 p 406

questions.text: A specimen of thick, bloody sputum from a hospitalized 70-year-old patient with diabetes mellitus and difficulty in breathing is sent for laboratory analysis. The tests yield heavy growth of a lactose-positive, nonmotile, gram-negative rod with a large capsule. Which of the following bacteria is Most likely to be the cause of pulmonary problems?
questions.solution:
Whereas all of the above-listed organisms are gram-negative rods, only K. pneumoniae fulfills all of the laboratory criteria listed in the question, such as the presence of a very large capsule, which gives a striking mucoid appearance to its colonies.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Panikers' Textbook of Microbiology third edition, pg. 614

questions.text: All of the following are type IV hypersensitivity reactions except:
questions.solution:
Polyarteritis nodosa is a type I hypersensitivity reaction, not type IV. Type iv hypersensitivity reactions (delayed hypersensitivity reactions): These reactions are Induced by sensitized T cells that, on contact with the specific antigen, release cytokines that It produces biological effects on leucocytes, macrophages, and tissue cells.

Examples of type IV hypersensitivity reactions include sarcoidosis, leprosy, type I lepra reaction, Psoriasis, inflammatory bowel disease, multiple sclerosis, diabetes mellitus, contact dermatitis. Type II hypersensitivity reactions are induced by immune complexes which deposit in tissues or blood vessels and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating the Complement system The inflammatory reaction causes tissue injury.

Other examples of type II hypersensitivity reactions include systemic lupus erythematosus, Serum sickness, Arthus reaction, post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, rheumatoid arthritis and type ll lepra reaction.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Panikers Textbook of Microbiology Tenth edition pg no 169

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presented with a 3-day history of mucopurulent cervical discharge. Gram staining of the discharge revealed numerous pus cells but no organisms. What is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis of this infection?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical history, the most likely diagnosis is acute cervicitis. As gram stain does not show any organism, gonococcal infection is less likely. In this case, Chlamydia trachomatis is the Most likely organism. For C. trachomatis, the investigation of choice is the nucleic Acid Amplification test (NAAT).

NAATS are the most sensitive tests to detect chlamydia. These tests also have high specificity Compared to culture, and in contrast to culture, does not depend on viable pathogens. Therefore, NAATS are generally considered the test of choice for chlamydia and have replaced culture as the diagnostic gold standard.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th Edition Page No. 1319

questions.text: A sudden epidemic of pneumonic plague has occurred in the Beed-Latur belt of Maharashtra. The primary contact of a suspected case came to you for preventive Treatment What will you prescribe for chemoprophylaxis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The Doc for the prophylaxis of plague is Ciprofloxacin. It is given for 7 days to all Close contact of a patient having pneumonic plague Doxycycline and tetracycline can also be used for antimicrobial prophylaxis.

The drug of choice for the treatment of plague is streptomycin. Streptomycin is nephrotoxic and ototoxic and should, therefore, be cautiously used. Doxycycline, or Ciprofloxacin (and other Fluoroquinolones are considered alternative drugs for the treatment of plague

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th Edition Pg 1204

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for invasive pulmonary aspergillosis?

The other options can be used as alternatives for the treatment of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis if voriconazole is unavailable.

questions.text: An immunologist has arranged a series of tubes for an experiment on precipitation reaction. The tubes contain equal amounts of antiserum while increasing quantities of antigen are added from left to right. One of the middle Tubes shows maximum precipitation. What is the phenomenon observed in the Tubes to the left of the middle tube?
questions.solution:
The phenomenon observed in the tubes to the left of the middle tube is called the Prozone Phenomenon. Rarely, antibodies are in excess compared to antigens, leading to weak or absent precipitation.

Lattice hypothesis explains precipitation reactions and agglutination reactions.

The prozone phenomenon is caused by excessive antibodies in the test system. There is Weak/absent precipitation, giving a false negative test.

Zone of equivalence- Antigen, and antibody are in optimum proportions and maximum Precipitation occurs. Lattice formation is enhanced. (tube in the middle in question stem)

The post-zone phenomenon is due to the presence of excessive antigens in the test system.

There is weaker/absent precipitation. (tubes on the right side in question stem)

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Panikers Textbook of Microbiolog Tenth edition pg no 107

questions.text: Your patient is a 60-year-old man with abdominal pain, vomiting, and weight loss for the past 2 months. He has a history of asthma that requires 20 mg of prednisone daily to control. An abdominal exam is normal, and radiographic studies are unrevealing. His white blood cell count is 10,900 with 16% eosinophils. Examination of the stool reveals rhabditiform larvae. Of the following, which organism is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The eggs of S. stercoralis usually hatch within the mucosa, forming rhabditiform larvae that are passed in the feces. Some Larvae molt to form filariform larvae, which penetrate the intestinal wall directly without Leaving the host and migrate to the lungs (autoinfection). Filariform larvae can also exit the anus and reinfection through the perianal Skin. In immunocompetent patients, this is an infrequent, clinically unimportant event. However, in immunocompromised patients (e.g. Those who have acquired immunodeficiency Syndrome [AIDS] or are taking high-dose Corticosteroids) or patients who are severely Malnourished, autoinfection can lead to Massive reinfection, with larvae passing to Many organs and with severe, sometimes fatal Consequences.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Panikers' Textbook of Microbiology, 3rd edition, pg. 465

questions.text: Which of the following IPC sections is not related to grievous injury?
questions.solution:
IPC Section 319 defines hurt (not grievous hurt) as including bodily pain, infirmity, or disease caused to any individual.

Grievous hurt or injury is defined to include injuries such as emasculation, permanent damage to eyesight(either eye), permanent damage to hearing(either ear), damage to any member or joint, destruction or permanent impairment of the power of any member or joint, permanent disfigurement of the head or face, fracture or dislocation of bone or tooth, and any injury that endangers the victim's life or causes them severe bodily pain, thereby impairing their ability to follow their daily routine for a period of 20 days.

Other options

  • Section 320--defines grievous hurt
  • Section 326-Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt by a dangerous weapon(imprisonment up to 10 years with a fine)
  • Section 331: Causing grievous hurt to extort confession. (imprisonment up to 10 years with a fine). (imprisonment up to 10 years with a fine).

Other IPC sections related to grievous harm:

  • Sec 322: Voluntary causation of grievous hurt.
  • Sec 325: Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt (imprisonment up to 7 years with fine)
  • Sec 329: Causing grievous hurt to extort property (imprisonment up to 10 years with fine)
  • Sec 333: Causing hurt to deter public servant from the duty (imprisonment up to 10 years with fine)
  • Sec 335: Causing grievous hurt on grave or sudden provocations (imprisonment with 4 years + or fine)
  • Sec 338: Causing grievous hurt by an act endangering the life or safety of others (imprisonment with 2 years + or -fine)

References: Review Of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology, Including Clinical And Pathological Aspects

questions.text:
A 14-year-old girl comes to the OPD with her mother. A history of penovaginal penetration by the neighbor is reported to the doctor. The girl admits to giving the neighbor consent for the same and says she does not want to be examined. As a medical officer, which of the following should you do?
1. Document informed refusal
2. Do not inform the police.
3. Counsel the mother and daughter
4. Examine with the necessary force.
5. Inform the police.
questions.solution:
In the given scenarios 1, 3, and 5 are true.

The scenario describes a 14-year-old girl with a history of sexual intercourse with her neighbor, albeit with consent. Consent for intercourse is valid only after 18 years in an unmarried girl. As she is less than 18 years old, it is presumed to be a medicolegal case of sexual assault.

Examination of a victim of sexual assault should be done with the consent of the victim (if she is less than 12 years of age or of unsound mind, consent from the guardian needs to be obtained). If she denies examination, counseling has to be done regarding the need for examination and how it could be held against her in a court of law. If she still refuses part or whole of the examination or sample collection, an informed refusal needs to be documented.

Information to the police is given in all medicolegal cases.

Reference: Textbook of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 2nd edition Page no 372

choices.text: Parboiling is effective in toxin removal
The active principle is beta-oxalyl amino alanine
Onset of spastic paraplegia is within 1 week
Vitamin C is used as prophylaxis

questions.text: A farmer based out of Central India presents with a cross-leg gait. When asked about his diet, he says that he consumes the pulses that he grows. A picture of the pulses is shown below. Which of the following statements is not true regarding them?
questions.solution:
The image shows the Kesari dal (Lathyrus sativus). Prolonged consumption for more than 6 months can lead to a condition called neurolathyrism, which is characterized by spastic paraplegia, exaggerated deep tendon reflexes, ankle clonus, and a positive Babinski's sign.

Kesari dal is the staple dal for the low-income population in India. The seeds have a triangular shape and a grey color, but look identical to red gram when dehusked. It contains a toxin called beta-oxalyl amino alanine. Disease symptoms develop in phases (acute, subacute, and insidious). Initial manifestations include short, jerky steps that progress to a cross-leg gait and later, to spastic paraplegia.

The ideal way to reduce toxicity is to abstain from consuming this dal. This is not as feasible in low-income populations that rely on these pulses due to their affordability. Alternatively, parboiling or steeping the seeds in hot water for about an hour is very effective in removing the majority concentration of the toxin (beta oxalyl amino alanine) from them. Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) is a potential agent for prophylaxis against the disease (daily administration of 0.5-1 gram for a week).

References: The Essentials Of Forensio Medicine And Toxicology 33rd edition Page No. 630
