questions.text: If an infant has immediate airway distress on delivery, which is least likely to be the cause?
questions.solution:

The symptoms of laryngeal webs are present at birth in 75% of patients with them. Forty percent of saccular cysts are discovered in a few hours after birth. questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with a 3-day history of redness and photophobia in his right eye. He vaguely remembers having redness of this same eye 6 months ago that resolved spontaneously. He denies trauma what is probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
HSV keratitis is caused by the herpes simplex virus, a double-stranded DNA virus made up of an icosahedral shaped capsid surrounding a core of DNA and phosphoproteins of viral chromatin. HSV-I and HSV-II are differentiated by virus-specific antigens. HSV-I typically affects the orofacial region, whereas HSV-II usually causes genital infections, though studies have shown that both viruses may affect either location.

Risk Factors

Risk factors for the development of primary HSV involve direct contact with infected secretions or lesions.

Risk factors for reactivation of disease have been postulated to include:

  • Sunlight
  • Trauma
  • Heat
  • Menstruation
  • Stress
  • Trigeminal nerve manipulation
  • Infectious diseases and immunocompromised states.

General Pathology

Corneal scrapings of HSV keratitis prepared with Giemsa stain may reveal the presence of intranuclear viral inclusion bodies. Multinucleated giant cells may also be found. With complete stromal inflammation, a granulomatous reaction may be seen, usually at the level of Descemet's membrane.

Pathophysiology

Ocular herpetic disease is more frequently caused by HSV-I, which is presumed to gain access to the cornea via the trigeminal nerve from an oral infection or direct contact with infected secretions. Initial infection typically remains asymptomatic, but patients may present with acute follicular conjunctivitis and an upper respiratory infection. After the primary infection, the virus travels via sensory nerve axons to establish a latent infection in the trigeminal ganglion where it resides permanently. The virus is then capable of reactivation along any branch of the trigeminal nerve to cause ocular morbidity.

Primary prevention

Prevention of herpetic infection includes avoidance of direct contact with lesions and secretions of a patient with active HSV.

History

Key aspects to inquire about in the history of patients with suspected HSV include past infections (history of recurrent 'red eye', particularly unilateral), underlying systemic diseases, immunosuppression or immunocompromised state, history of eyelid lesions, and history of oral and genital ulcers.

Physical examination

In addition to the standard biomicroscopy, special attention should be paid to the presence of a preauricular lymph node, vesicular lesions on the lids or adnexa, bulbar follicles, decreased corneal sensation, and most notably, the presence of epithelial dendrites on the cornea.

For primary HSV keratitis, it is more common for patients to present with blepharoconjunctivitis than with corneal involvement. However, diffuse punctate keratopathy or corneal microcysts may be visible.

Recurrent HSV keratitis can be present as epithelial keratitis. The earliest signs of epithelial disease include raised clear vesicles that later coalesce to form the classic dendritic lesion. The dendritic ulcer, the dichotomous branching cornea lesion, can be stained with fluorescein and is the hallmark of HSV epithelial keratitis. These epithelial lesions represent active replicating viruses. The dendritic ulcer may evolve into a geographic ulceration of the cornea, especially in patients with compromised immunity or on topical steroids.

Reference: Parsons 22/e, P. 40

questions.text: A researcher wants to study how smoking electronic cigarettes affects the risk of developing lung cancer. Which of the following would be the most appropriate set of experimental and control groups for her cohort study, respectively?
questions.solution:
This researcher is conducting a cohort study, which compares subjects who are exposed to a risk factor, in this case, smoking, with patients who are not exposed to that risk factor.

Cohort studies are observational studies that seek to determine whether a risk factor contributes to the development of a disease process. They can be either prospective or retrospective, and they compare a group with a given risk factor to a group without the risk factor to see if there is an increased likelihood of developing the disease. The classic statistical measure used to analyze cohort studies is the relative risk, which asks how much more likely a subject is to have the disease if they are exposed to the risk factor. On a 2x2 table this measure can be represented as [a/(a+b)] / [c/(c+d)].

Reference: Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, by K. Park, 26th Edition, Page Number 60

questions.text: An RCT is investigating the effects of different diagnostic imaging modalities on breast cancer mortality. The conventional mammography group has a median survival after diagnosis of 17.0 years. The MRI plus conventional mammography group has a median survival of 19.5 years. If this difference is statistically significant, which form of bias may be affecting the results?
questions.solution:
Lead-time bias occurs when an increased ability to detect disease increases the survival time after diagnosis without changing the course of the disease.

Despite the fact that randomized controlled trials (RCTs) are considered the gold standard in determining clinical efficacy, they are not completely immune to bias. Lead-time biases are especially problematic in RCTs that are investigating the efficacy of new diagnostic procedures. The hope of new diagnostic procedures is that detecting disease earlier will improve prognosis. The potential for lead time bias clouds this picture, as the detection of disease before it becomes symptomatic will result in an apparent prolongation of survival after diagnosis, even if early detection has no impact on the natural history of the disease.

Reference: Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, by K. Park, 26th Edition, Page Number 60

questions.text: Based on these findings, which of the following is the most likely correlation coefficient?
questions.solution:
In the descriptive analysis of data, a scatter plot can be helpful to ascertain whether there is an association between two variables. The correlation coefficient (r) represents the strength of the linear relationship between two variables (i.e., how close the data points are to a straight line of regression) as well as the polarity of the relationship.

A correlation coefficient (r) of 0.45 reflects a moderately strong positive linear correlation between maternal BMI and childhood BMI. While there is a clear positive trend (i.e., as one variable increases, the other variable also tends to increase), the points on the scatter plot do not cluster into a straight line, indicating that the relationship is moderately strong but not a perfect correlation. Correlation does not imply causation. It merely shows whether a linear relationship exists between the two variables and how strong it is.

The r coefficient is a measure of the strength and directionality of a linear relationship between two variables. However, it has no bearing on the slope of the line of best fit (which is not shown in this scatter plot).

Reference: Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, by K. Park, 26th Edition, Page Number 60

The data set follows a normal distribution
The median is greater than the mean
The mean and mode are equal

questions.text: Which of the following statements about this data set is most accurate?
questions.solution:
The histogram shows an asymmetrical distribution with a long tail pointing to the positive direction of the scale.

A data set that follows a right-skewed distribution (positively skewed distribution) is clustered on the left side of the scale with a long tail on the right (positive direction of the scale), as seen here. Such a distribution usually has the following inequality between the measures of central tendency: mean > median > mode.

Reference: Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, by K. Park, 26th Edition, Page Number 60.

questions.text: In a family of 16 people, the first case of hemolytic uremic syndrome was reported in the last week of April. Based on the graph, which of the following is the attack rate among the individuals at risk in the month of May?
questions.solution:
The attack rate is the ratio of new cases to the number of individuals at risk.

The attack rate (cumulative incidence) is calculated by dividing the number of individuals who contracted an illness in a given period of time by the number of individuals who were at risk of contracting that illness during this time. According to this graph, 6 people contracted HUS in May (patient 1 was ill before May; patient 6 fell ill in June). The number of people at risk of contracting HUS in May is 15, as patient 1 was already ill in April and, thus, was not at risk of contracting HUS in May.

Patient 6 was at risk of contracting the illness throughout May and is included as an exposed individual. However, since the illness did not manifest until June, it is not calculated as a part of the attack rate in May. Therefore, the attack rate of HUS for May is 6/15.

Reference: Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, by K. Park, 26th Edition, Page Number 60.

questions.text: Which color tag is attached to a dead person during triage after a devastating earthquake?
questions.solution:
In medicine, triage is a practice invoked when acute care cannot be provided for a lack of resources. The process rations care towards those who are most in need of immediate care, and who benefit most from it. More generally, it refers to the prioritization of medical care as a whole. In its acute form, it is most often required on the battlefield, during a pandemic, or when an accident results in a mass casualty that overwhelms the nearby healthcare facilities' capacity.

Colour code followed during triage is as follows:

RED: immediate medical attention

YELLOW: medical attention required

GREEN: can wait for medical attention (walking wounded)

BLACK: dead persons

Reference: Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, by K. Park, 26th Edition, Page Number 889

questions.text: Which is not the phase of the disaster management cycle?
questions.solution:
The Disaster Management Cycle has five phases:

  1. Disaster
  2. Response: Emergency response is given by the local state disaster management teams in terms of Search & Rescue and Emergency Relief
  3. Recovery includes reconstruction and rehabilitation.
  4. Mitigation: taking steps legally and politically to prevent the next disaster from even happening.
  5. Preparedness: Stay prepared for early warnings and signs of an impending disaster.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines is essential for travel to African countries?
questions.solution:
The Yellow Fever vaccine is essential before traveling to African countries. Once the Yellow Fever vaccine is taken, it is valid for 7-10 days and it is valid for the next 35 years.

17D is the vaccine strain given for Yellow Fever. It is a live vaccine and is contraindicated during pregnancy.

Yellow Fever virus-

Reservoir: primary monkeys

Vector: mosquito (after inoculation, the virus replicates in dendritic cells)

Yellow fever is an acute viral infection caused by the yellow fever virus. Primates are the main reservoir of the virus, which is usually transmitted through bites from infected mosquitoes. Yellow fever is endemic in large parts of South America and Africa. The incubation period is 3-6 days, and the majority of patients remain asymptomatic or experience only mild symptoms. Symptomatic patients initially present with nonspecific symptoms such as sudden-onset fever, malaise, headaches, chills, nausea, and myalgia. There is no causal treatment available, making prevention of crucial importance. A single dose of a live-attenuated vaccine provides lifelong protection for most individuals.

Reference: Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, by K. Park, 26th Edition, Page Number 158

questions.text: What is the objective of the Rashtriya Vayoshri Yojana?
questions.solution:
Rashtriya Vayoshri Yojana (RVY) is a scheme for providing physical aids and assisted-living devices for senior citizens belonging to the BPL category. This is a Central Sector Scheme, fully funded by the Central Government. The expenditure for implementation of the scheme will be met by the 'Senior Citizens Welfare Fund'. The Scheme will be implemented through the sole implementing agency-Artificial Limbs Manufacturing Corporation (ALIMCO), a PSU under the Ministry of Social Justice and Empowerment.

Under the scheme, physical aid will be provided only to the senior citizens of the nation. This implies those who are aged above 60 years will get free assisted living aids and physical devices that are required for their sustainability. Also, the government has selected the list of cities where the scheme will be implemented. The main criteria for senior citizens to get full benefits of the Rashtriya Vayoshri Yojana (RVY) scheme is that they must belong to a BPL family and should hold a valid BPL card issued by the concerned authority.

questions.text: A cohort study was undertaken to study an association between green tea intake and diabetes mellitus and found a relative risk of 0.85. Which of the following is correct?
questions.solution:
Relative risk (RR; risk ratio)-

Description:

The likelihood of an outcome in one group exposed to a potential risk factor is compared to the risk in another group that has not been exposed.

Purpose:

  1. To measure how strongly a risk factor is associated with an outcome (e.g., death, injury, disease)
  2. To help establish disease etiology.

Used in:

Cohort studies and randomized controlled trials

Formula:

(incidence of disease in exposed group)/(incidence of disease in unexposed group) = (a/(a + b))/(c/(c + d))

Interpretation

RR = 1: Exposure neither increases nor decreases the risk of the defined outcome.

RR > 1: Exposure increases the risk of the outcome.

RR < 1: Exposure decreases the risk of the outcome.

Reference: Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, by K. Park, 26th Edition, Page Number 60

choices.text: The risk is higher in study B because the prevalence in study B is 9 cases per 300 patients
The risk is higher in study A because the incidence rate in study A is 30 cases per 10 person-years
The risks are equivalent because the prevalence in both studies is 39 cases per 3300 persons
The risks are equivalent because the incidence rate in both studies is 1 case per 1000 person-years

questions.text:
Number of patients
Study A 3000
Study B 300
Mean followup period
Study A 10 years
Study B 30 years
The number of new cases of lymphoma
Study A 30
Study B 9
Based on these results, which of the following statements about the risk of lymphoma is most accurate?
questions.solution:
The incidence rate (IR), or person-time rate, is a measure of risk that can be used when comparing groups with different followup periods. IR = (number of new cases)/(total person-time observation). The total person-time observation for a study is the time each person was observfollow-uped, totaled for all persons in the study. Alternatively, total person-time observation = (number of people observed) × (mean follow-up period).

The IR in study A is (30 cases)/(3000 persons × 10 years) = 1 case per 1000 person-years. The IR in study B is (9 cases)/(300 persons × 30 years) = 1 case per 1000 person-years. The IRs in both studies are the same and the risk is therefore equivalent. Absolute risk (AR), which is the likelihood of an event occurring under specific conditions, is equivalent to cumulative incidence or incidence proportion (IP). IP = (number of new cases in a specific time period)/(number of people at risk). AR or IP is not a useful measure of risk when the follow-up periods are different.

Reference: Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, by K. Park, 26th Edition, Page Number 60

questions.text: Changing the cutoff value to 750/mm3 from 500/mm3, how would affect the test performance of ANC with regard to agranulocytosis in which of the following ways?
questions.solution:
Keep in mind that this is a low-value test: raising the cutoff from 500/mm3 to 750/mm3 means that the patients who have agranulocytosis are more likely to be identified as such. However, extending the criteria for agranulocytosis has a disadvantage.

What happens when a cutoff value is raised or lowered depends on whether the test in question requires a high value (e.g., tumor marker for cancer, lipase for pancreatitis) or a low value (e.g., hyponatremia, agranulocytosis). For a low-value test, such as this one, raising the cutoff value to 750/mm3 (i.e., broadening the inclusion criteria for agranulocytosis) would result in an increase in true and false positives, while true and false negatives would decrease.

In other words, increasing the inclusion criteria leads to more patients with the disease being identified as such, while at the same time resulting in an increased number of individuals under suspicion for agranulocytosis who do not actually have the disease. This would make the test more sensitive but less specific. It would also lead to a decreased positive predictive value and an increased negative predictive value. High sensitivity is usually achieved at the expense of specificity. Only a test with 100% specificity and 100% sensitivity would correctly identify all true positive and all true negative individuals.

Reference: Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, by K. Park, 26th Edition, Page Number 150

questions.text: A screening camp for anemia was held for 500 girls on a given day as part of the Anemia Mukt Bharat program. The screening was done by checking Hb levels with a new screening method, and a cut-off value of 11 g% was set. It was found that out of 500 girls, 200 were classified as anemic. However, on detailed work-up, only 125 had anemia. Similarly, of the other 20 girls who tested negative, 20 actually had anemia. What are the specificity and sensitivity of this test, respectively?
questions.solution:
Specificity is the probability of choosing true negatives out of the total classified as disease negative.

Thus, specificity is d/b+d*100

I.e, 280/300 * 100=93.33%

Sensitivity is the probability of choosing true positives out of the total diseased positive population.

Thus, sensitivity = a/a+c * 100

I.e, 125/200 * 100= 62.5%

questions.text: A 35 year old male patient presented to the emergency department with the history of road traffic accident. Patient is in grade IV hemorrhagic shock with grade IV splenic injury diagnosed on FAST scan. Patient has been transfused with 4 units of whole blood in the emergency department. Which among the following complications is not being encountered in this patient?
questions.solution:
As the patient is being transfused with 4 units of blood in the emergency department, so massive transfusion protocol has been administered.

Option a, c and d are the complications of massive blood transfusion

Option b - hypocalcemia is the complication of massive blood transfusion and not hypercalcemia

Complications of blood transfusion

Complications from blood transfusion can be categorised as those arising from a single transfusion and those related to massive transfusion.

Complications from a single transfusion Complications from a single transfusion include:

  • incompatibility hemolytic transfusion reaction;
  • febrile transfusion reaction;
  • allergic reaction;
  • infection:
  • bacterial infection (usually due to faulty storage);
  • hepatitis;
  • HIV;
  • malaria;
  • air embolism;
  • thrombophlebitis;
  • transfusion-related acute lung injury (usually from FFP). Complications from massive transfusion

Complications from massive transfusion include:

  • coagulopathy;
  • hypocalcaemia;
  • hyperkalaemia;
  • hypokalemia;
  • hypothermia.

In addition, patients who receive repeated transfusions over long periods of time (e.g. patients with thalassemia) may develop iron overload. (Each transfused unit of red blood cells contains approximately 250 mg of elemental iron.)

Reference: love and bailey 27th edition page 22

questions.text: A young female is taken up for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. When should be the prophylactic antibiotic given to this patient?
questions.solution:
• If antibiotics are given to prevent infection after surgery or instrumentation, they should be used before bacterial growth becomes established (i.e. within the decisive period).
  • Ideally, maximal blood and tissue levels should be present at the time at which the first incision is made and before contamination
  • Tissue levels of the antibiotic should remain high throughout the operation and antibiotics with a short tissue half-life should be
  • Intravenous administration at induction of anaesthesia is therefore optimal, as unexpected delays in the timing of surgery may occur before then and antibiotic tissue levels may fall off before the surgery
  • In long operations or when there is excessive blood loss, or when unexpected contamination occurs, antibiotics may be repeated at 4-hourly intervals during the surgery, because tissue antibiotic levels often fall faster than serum

questions.text: A 20 years old male presents with hard painless testicular swelling. On investigation, AFP is 3080 ng/ml. No para-aortic or iliac nodes as well as no mediastinal lymph nodes found. Ultrasound shows uniform echotexture and small areas of necrosis. Surrounding structures are normal. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
• The next best step for this patient would be a High Inguinal orchidectomy which will act as diagnostic as well as staging modality.
  • The orchidectomy is undertaken via an inguinal
  • The spermatic cord is displayed by dividing the external oblique aponeurosis and a soft clamp is placed across the cord to stop dissemination of malignant cells as the testis is mobilized into the wound.
  • Rarely, if there is doubt about the diagnosis, the testis should be bisected along its anterior convexity to examine its internal
  • If there is a tumour the cord should be double transfixed and divided at the level of the internal inguinal ring and the testis

questions.text: A neonate is found to have abdominal distention and failure to pass meconium in first 24 hours. When evaluated with contrast enema found to have microcolon with abrupt cut off, post enema the child was relived of symptoms. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A) A contrast enema using the water-soluble ionic solution gastrografin can both be diagnostic, demonstrating a small, narrow-caliber colon however no micro colon and inspissated meconium pellets{(not seen in meconium plug syndrome)in the terminal ileum however no abrupt cut off or transition zone is seen}, as well as therapeutic, as it aids in the evacuation of meconium by pulling water into the colon.

Option B) In Colonic atresia A plain radiograph shows multiple dilated bowel loops, but differentiation between small and large bowel is not feasible in this age group because of lack of well-developed haustra and semicircularis landmarks. A contrast enema study can confirm the diagnosis, but the clinical picture of distal bowel obstruction may be enough evidence to proceed with an operative intervention of diverting end colostomy

Option C) Infants often present with abdominal distention and failure to pass meconium in the first 24 hours. The contrast enema study shows a microcolon extending up to where the colon is dilated, and filled with a thickened meconium plug. Often, a contrast enema is therapeutic and surgical intervention is not indicated.

Option D) The diagnostic imaging study of choice in a newborn is a contrast enema. In Hirschsprung disease, spasm of the distal rectum usually results in a narrow caliber with a transition zone and dilated,normal, proximal sigmoid colon. Failure to evacuate the instilled contrast medium completely after 24 hours strongly indicates the presence of Hirschsprung disease.

Ref: sabiston 21 ed pg. 1860

The mother experiences a sense of relief from the mechanical cardiorespiratory embarrassment. In short mother feels light.

questions.text: Contraindications of ECV include all except-
questions.solution:
• ECV- External Cephalic Version is a procedure that externally rotates the fetus from a breech presentation to a vertex presentation.

Contraindications-

  • Antepartum hemorrhage
  • Fetal factors- EFW > 3.5 kg, dead fetus, congenital anomalies, IUGR
  • Multiple pregnancy
  • Ruptured membranes- with drainage of liquor
  • Known congenital malformation of the uterus
  • Fetal distress
  • Contracted pelvis
  • Previous more than 1 cesarean delivery
  • Obstetric complications- bad obstetric history, severe preeclampsia, oligohydramnios
  • Rh isoimmunization

Breech with extended legs is associated with higher chances of failure of version due to early engagement of presenting part and difficult to flex the trunk because of splinting action of the limbs.

But it is not a contraindication for ECV.

questions.text: A 35-year-old, nulliparous woman has come with the c/o abnormal uterine bleeding for 1 year. Her cycles are regular, bleeding lasts for 7-8 days, with passage of clots, soaking 3-4 pads/day. There is no c/o pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea. What is the investigation of choice?

    • Cheap

questions.text: The endometrial sampling is normal. But the woman has persistent complain of bleeding. What should be the next best step-
questions.solution:
Approach to postmenopausal bleeding:

  • Per speculum examination- if growth- biopsy.
  • ET < 4 mm- atrophic endometritis more likely.
  • Observe and follow up.
  • If ET ≥ 4 mm- endometrial aspiration to look for endometrial hyperplasia and endometrial carcinoma.
  • After aspiration sample is sent for histopathological examination.
  • If histopathology comes normal but patient is having persistent bleeding- fractional curettage preferably with hysteroscopy under GA.
  • So fractional curettage is considered as a gold standard investigation.

Reference: ACOG guideline for the evaluation of woman with post-menopausal bleeding.

questions.text: An ECG performed of a newborn show following tracing. False statement about the condition is?
questions.solution:
• The tracing above is consistent with atrial flutter.
  • Atrial flutter is a re-entrant tachycardia contained within the atrium.
  • The tachycardia classically conducts in a counterclockwise loop, which comprises the atrial septum, the lateral wall of the right atrium, and the tricuspid valve. It has a 'sawtooth' configuration on EKG.
  • The rate of atrial flutter, if conducted 1:1, is usually 300 beats per minute but this some patients may have a 2:1 block at a rate of 200 beats per minute. It may be difficult to differentiate the P waves at this rate and the tracing may appear to be consistent with supraventricular tachycardia.
  • If the neonate is stable, initial treatment with digoxin to block the ventricular rate is indicated. If the neonate is unstable, direct current (DC) synchronized cardioversion or esophageal pacing followed by digoxin is recommended.
  • If there is no underlying etiology, affected neonates are expected to have a good prognosis with recurrence unlikely.

Reference: Park's Pediatric cardiology, 6th ed., pg. 414

questions.text: You are called to see a full-term infant who shows bluish discoloration of skin and lips, tachypnea, and a sharp drop in oxygen saturation within the first 30 minutes of birth. On examination, she has normal heart sounds, normal liver edge, and oxygen saturation between 50-60%. When placed on respiratory support on the best settings and 100% oxygen, the oxygen saturation remains 70-75%. A chest X-ray is performed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• This patient's clinical findings and 'egg on a string' appearance of the heart are characteristics of transposition of the great arteries. In this congenital heart defect, the aorta arises from the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery arises from the left ventricle. This results in deoxygenated venous blood flowing back to the systemic circulation while oxygenated pulmonary venous blood flows back to the lungs.
  • Patients are typically presented with Cyanosis in the 1 day of life, acute management includes prostaglandin E1 or/and a balloon atrial septostomy to expand the ductus arteriosus and facilitate inter-circulatory mixing. Once the patient is stabilized, corrective surgery should be performed as early as possible.

Reference: Park's Pediatric cardiology, 6th ed., pg. 209

questions.text: Seizures in cholera is commonly due to
questions.solution:
• Seizure is one of the complications of cholera if treatment is not initiated timely.
  • Delayed initiation of rehydration therapy or inadequate rehydration often leads to complications.
  • Renal failure from prolonged hypotension can occur. Unless potassium supplementation is provided, hypokalemia can lead to nephropathy and focal myocardial necrosis.
  • Hypoglycemia is common among children and can lead to seizures unless it is appropriately corrected.

questions.text: The following specific antinuclear antibodies and their associations are false:

Sd is specific for scleroderma and Ro/SSA for annular erythema, Sjogren's syndrome and congenital heart block. La/SSB is specific for Sjogren's syndrome, while Pm-Sd is specific for sclero-dermato-myositis.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy has a history of recurrent sinusitis and multiple episodes of pneumonia. A sweat electrolyte test result is within the normal range. Which of the following can be removed from your differential diagnosis now?
questions.solution:
• Children with severe combined immunodeficiency will present in the first few months of life, and without stem cell transplant most die in the first year of life.
  • CF cannot be ruled out since there can be false-negative test results; the sweat chloride test should be repeated and a full review of systems for other gastrointestinal or genitourinary symptoms should be done.
  • Bronchiectasis and chronic sinusitis are characteristic of ciliary dyskinesia syndromes. Recurrent pneumonia and sinusitis can occur as complications of GERD and atopic disease.

questions.text: An institutionalized male juvenile delinquent upon close examination has severe nodulocystic acne, mild pectus excavatum, large teeth, prominent glabella, and relatively long face and fingers. His family says he has poor fine motor skills (such as penmanship), an explosive temper, and a low-normal IQ. What is the most likely diagnosis?

questions.text:
In the emergency department the nurse is running toward the resuscitation room with a limp, cyanotic, pulseless, apneic, 11-month-old child in his arms. The child was previously healthy. One provider begins giving bag-mask ventilations with 100% FiO2 while another establishes intraosseous access, and a third begins administering high-quality chest compressions. The following rhythm is seen on the monitor.

Of the following, the BEST next step in the management of this patient is
questions.solution:
• The patient described in this vignette has pulseless ventricular tachycardia. Therefore, the best next step, after starting high-quality cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) is defibrillation.
  • Ventricular fibrillation and pulseless ventricular tachycardia should be treated with early defibrillation before other interventions (e.g., epinephrine administration, endotracheal intubation), and pulse check should not delay defibrillation.
  • The dose for the initial defibrillation attempt is 2 J/kg.
  • Rhythms that should be treated with synchronized cardioversion include unstable supraventricular tachycardia, atrial tachycardia, and ventricular tachycardia with a pulse.

Reference: Pediatric advanced life support manual

questions.text:
A patient presented with breathlessness. On doing a CTPA, the following image was obtained.

What is the patient most likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
• Pulmonary hypertension is defined as a resting mean pulmonary arterial pressure of ≥25 mmHg at right heart catheterization, which is a hemodynamic feature that is shared by all types of pulmonary hypertension.
  • High-resolution CT (HRCT) chest, of course, is indispensable in assessing the lung parenchyma and identifying possible causative processes (e.g. interstitial lung disease, COPD, etc.).
  • In pulmonary capillary haemangiomatosis, small ill-defined centrilobular nodules and interlobular septal thickening may be apparent.
  • Additionally, routine CT chest and CT pulmonary angiography (CTPA) can also identify changes in the pulmonary vasculature and the heart.
  • Features include:
    • enlarged pulmonary trunk (measured at pulmonary artery bifurcation on an axial slice vertical to its long axis)
      • >29 mm diameter is often used as a general predictive cut-off.
    • main pulmonary artery (pulmonary trunk) to ascending aorta ratio
      • higher ratio correlates with higher PA pressure

Reference: Gaillard, F., Weerakkody, Y. Pulmonary hypertension. Reference article, Radiopaedia.org. https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-8843

questions.text: In which condition is the following deformity seen?
questions.solution:
• Erlenmeyer flask deformity (EFD), also known as metaphyseal flaring, refers to a radiographic appearance typically on a femoral radiograph demonstrating relatively reduced constriction of the diaphysis and flaring of the metaphysis as a result of undertubulation.
  • The name refers to the resemblance to a flat-bottomed titration flask used by chemists (known as a conical flask in British English).

questions.text: Which of the following is used in nuclear radiology to detect the radiation emitted from the radiopharmaceutical?
questions.solution:
The gamma scintillation camera converts photons emitted by the radionuclide in the patient's body into a light pulse, which is then subsequently converted into a voltage signal, which is then used to form an image.

This is true for both 'conventional' nuclear medicine scintigraphy, as well as for imaging with positron emitting radionuclides.

The basic components of a gamma camera system are the collimator, the scintillation crystal, the photomultiplier tube array, the pulse height analyzer (PHA), and the control console with computer integration.

Each of these components contributes to the accurate localization of the radiotracer distribution within the patient.

Reference: Mc-Graw Hill speciality Board review Radiology page 710

  • Hemorrhage into the SAS is known as subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH).
  • Sometimes, blood in the SAS is refluxed into the cerebral ventricles, producing secondary intraventricular hemorrhage.

questions.text: Quantity of x-rays is determined by?

• The number (quantity) of x rays produced depends entirely on the number of electrons that flow from the filament to the target (anode) of the tube.
  • The x-ray tube current, measured in milliamperes (1 mA = 0.001 A), refers to the number of electrons flowing per second from the filament to the target.

questions.text: What Salter-Harris type of physeal injury does the diagram below denote?
questions.solution:
• Type II injuries have physeal and metaphyseal components, the fracture line extends from the physeal margin peripherally across a variable portion of the physis and exits into the metaphysis at the opposite end of the fracture.
  • The epiphyseal fragment thus comprises all of the epiphysis and some portion of the peripheral metaphysis (Thurston-Holland fragment or sign)

Mnemonic-Types of Salter-Harris fractures:

  • There are nine types of Salter-Harris fractures; of them types I to V are more common.
  • The mnemonic 'SALTER' can be used to help remember the first five types.
  • Type I-S-Slip (separated or straight across). Transverse fracture through the growth plate
  • Type II-A Away. The fracture lies away from the joint. A fracture through the growth plate and the metaphysis, sparing the epiphysis
  • Type III-L Lower. The fracture is below the physis in the epiphysis
  • Type IV-TE Through Everything. A fracture through all three elements of the bone, the growth plate, metaphysis, and epiphysis
  • Type V-R-Rammed (crushed) A compression fracture of the growth plate

Reference: Maheshwari ortho 5th edition page no 58

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient came to emergency department with fracture of femur shaft after 5 days of injury develops petechiae, respiratory distress and decreased sPO2. Possible diagnosis is
questions.solution:
A fat embolism is often caused by physical trauma such as fracture of long bone, soft tissue trauma and burns.

Clinical Feature:

  • Tachycardia, tachypnea, increased temperature, hypoxemia (decreased sPO2), hypercapnia, thrombocytopenia.
  • Pathognomonic sign: Petechial rash on the upper anterior portion of the body, including the chest, neck, upper arm, axilla, shoulder, oral mucosa and conjunctivae.
  • Crush injury is compression of extremities or other parts of the body that causes muscle swelling and/or neurological disturbances in the affected areas of the body, while crush syndrome is localized crush injury with systemic manifestations.
  • It is Characterized by major shock and renal failure after a crushing injury to skeletal muscle.
  • Hypostatic pneumonia is usually seen in elderly and debilitating patients.
  • It results from infection developing in the dependent portions of the lungs due to decreased ventilation of those areas, with resulting failure to drain bronchial secretions.

Reference: Maheshwari ortho 5th edition page no. 43.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for the patient having above fracture?
questions.solution:
• The picture shown above is a Galeazzi fracture dislocation (reverse Monteggia/Piedmont fracture).
  • There is a fracture of the lower third of radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.
  • The treatment of choice is open reduction and internal fixation with compress on plates
  • The counterpart of Galeazzi is Monteggia fracture-dislocation where there is a fracture of the upper third of ulna with dislocation of the radial head.
  • Both of these fractures are fractures of necessity, le, it is necessary to perform open reduction and internal fixation for best results.

Reference: Maheshwari ortho 5th edition page no 111.

questions.text: A 3-year male presented with progressive anemia, hepatosplenomegaly and osteomyelitis of jaw with pathological fracture, x-ray shows chalky white deposits on bone. Probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Osteopetrosis (also known as Marble bone disease, Albers- Schonberg disease).
  • Defect is in bone resorption due to abnormal function of osteoclasts.
  • Defective bone resorption results in uniformly thickened dense bones, often without distinction between cortical and cancellous regions.
  • The bones are dense but brittle therefore known as marble bone disease. Inheritance is both AD & AR*.
  • The AR form dies early in the life. The AD form is of milder variety.
  • Classical types:
    • Autosomal recessive (infantile and malignant)
    • Autosomal dominant (adult and benign) type I and type II
    • Autosomal recessive intermediate form
  • Clinical features in osteopetrosis are caused by an increased tendency to fractures and osteomyelitis.
  • Defect in bone modeling produces loss in hematopoietic function and resultant anemia and immunodeficiency, skull foramina fail to expand resulting in various cranial nerve palsies and Blindness
  • X-RAY FEATURES: Generalized osteosclerosis with thickening of both cortical and cancellous bones,
    • Absent medullary canal
    • Cube-like bones (carpals and tarsals)
    • Erlenmeyer flask deformity of metaphysis with broadening
    • Rugger-Jersey' spine
    • Endo bone formation (bone within bone appearance)

Reference: MANISH KUMAR VARSHNEY 1ST EDITION PAGE NO.96

questions.text: A 26-year-old man is brought into the emergency department after he is picked up by police for wandering around his neighborhood naked. On examination, the patient states that he is 'blessed by Jesus' after he started hearing Jesus's messages and believes that he is destined to do something 'catastrophically wonderful' for the world. He is alternately euphoric and then irritable with the examiner. He states that he wants to go home in the new car which he bought after selling his house. The urine drug screen is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this man?
questions.solution:
• The man is presenting with labile mood, inappropriate behavior, grandiose thoughts, and excessive spending, all hallmarks of bipolar disorder.
  • Because he is clearly manic at the moment, a cyclothymic disorder, with its smaller highs than full blown mania, is unlikely.
  • Narcissistic personality disorder does not present with frank psychosis. Schizophrenia would be unlikely to present with the labile mood and excessive spending.
  • Schizoaffective disorder would likely present with a background of psychosis with new affective symptoms superimposed.
  • Because we must assume there is no prior history beyond what we have been told in the scenario, bipolar disorder is the best fit.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, Eleventh edition, Chapter 8 Mood disorders, page no. 371

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy who presents with poor academic performance is assessed for his intelligence quotient by Bhatia Battery test. His Mental age comes to be around 9 years. According to his IQ what will be his level of Intellectual disability?
questions.solution:
• The upper limit of chronological age is 16 years.
  • According to this formula, IQ of this patient would be approximately 55 (Mental age 9 years/Chronological age 16 years *100).
  • Mild intellectual disability is defined when full scale IQ is in the range between 50-70. Hence, as this boy's IQ is 55, he is said to have Mild Intellectual disability.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 31 Child Psychiatry, Page number 1120.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male patient, presented with overdose of 64 tablets of Lorazepam. He was diagnosed with Schizophrenia since last 2 years and was taking treatment for the same. Prior to the illness, he was working competently as a medical officer. Which of the following is a risk factor for suicide in Schizophrenia patients?
questions.solution:
Risk factors which have been specifically associated with suicide among patients with schizophrenia include younger age, high socio-economic status, high premorbid scholastic achievement and high intelligence quotient, high aspirations and expectations, early age of onset, younger age at first hospitalization, a chronic and deteriorating course with multiple relapses and higher level of insight into the illness.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 7 Schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders, Page number 314.

choices.text: Leprosy in children manifests predominantly as PB disease
The disease presents as multiple erythematous patches on the buttocks
Leprosy in parents is not a major risk factor

questions.text: An 8-year-old child is referred to you from rural PHC for confirmation of diagnosis of leprosy, as his mother and father both had lepromatous leprosy. Which of the following statement is true about childhood leprosy?
questions.solution:
• Familial contacts form a high-risk group in families of leprosy patients.
  • Leprosy in children presents predominantly as PB disease.
  • The disease usually manifests as a single hypopigmented patch with normal or impaired sensation mainly on the exposed parts of body.
  • Pure neuritic Hansen and histoid Hansen is rare in children

Reference: IAL textbook of leprosy, 2nd edition page 363

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presented with 7-day history of painful genital ulcers. She had similar lesion in the past. H/o peno-vaginal intercourse a week earlier. On examination, following picture was appreciated. There was no lymphadenopathy. What is the likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
• Herpes genitals is an ulcerating, sexually transmitted infection, the clinical importance of which lies in its ability to produce painful and recurrent disease in addition to its potential role as a cofactor in acquisition and transmission of human immunodeficiency virus.
  • In recent years, there are increasing reports of genital herpes due to herpes simplex virus (HSV)-1 from various parts of the world.
  • Molecular diagnostic methods such as polymerase chain reaction (PCR) have got both diagnostic and prognostic significance in genital herpes.

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition chapter 30.19

questions.text: Which of the following type of reactive erythema is more closely associated with malignancy?
questions.solution:
• Clinical manifestations of Erythema gyratum repens:
  • It presents as a widespread, serpiginous, polycyclic and pruriginous erythema which is desquamative around the edges and fast-growing, about 1 cm/day, producing concentric figures that resemble a wood surface.
  • Hands and feet are often spared.
  • Other manifestations include palmoplantar keratosis, ichthyosis and onychodystrophy in the sacral region.
  • Associated malignancies: Malignant neoplasms are found in 82% of the patients with EGR. Lung cancer is the most common (32%), followed by cancer of the esophagus (8%) and breast (6%). 2, 9 Other malignancies have been associated with EGR, such as colon, stomach, bladder, prostate, uterine, rectal and pancreatic cancer and multiple myeloma. 9, 10, 1,7
  • The diagnosis of EGR precedes the diagnosis of the neoplasia in approximately 80% of patients, on average from four to nine months. 9, 15, 17
  • Non-neoplastic conditions may be rarely associated with EGR, such as tuberculosis, pregnancy, calcinosis, esophageal dysmotility, sclerodactyly, Sjogren's syndrome and CREST syndrome

Reference:Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition chapter 42
